qas.question: What primary body part is affected by tuberculosis?
Roughly, what percentage of latent tuberculosis infections result in active tuberculosis?
What name has been used to refer to tuberculosis because of associated weight loss?
Along with cough, weight loss, and night sweats, what's the fourth classic symptom of the disease?
What disease is caused by TB?
What percentage of infections do not have symptoms?
What is an infection with symptoms called?
What percentage of patients with latent TB die?

context: <b7_0>Tuberculosis<b7_0/> (TB) is an infectious disease usually caused by the <b5_0>bacterium <a0_0>Mycobacterium tuberculosis<a0_0/> (MTB)<b5_0/>. Tuberculosis generally affects the <a1_0>lungs<a1_0/>, but can also affect other parts of the body. Most infections do not have symptoms, known as <b8_0>latent tuberculosis<b8_0/>. About <a2_0><b6_0>10%<b6_0/><a2_0/> of latent infections progress to active disease which, if left untreated, kills about <b9_0>half<b9_0/> of those infected. The classic symptoms of active TB are a chronic cough with blood-containing sputum, <a4_0>fever<a4_0/>, night sweats, and weight loss. The historical term "<a3_0>consumption<a3_0/>" came about due to the weight loss. Infection of other organs can cause a wide range of symptoms.
